meaning_mnemonic: This is it. You're finally here. This is the moment where you learn the true meaning behind WaniKani!

If you do <kanji>not</kanji> have any <kanji>ethics</kanji> you'll probably do something crappy, like commit <vocabulary>adultery</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>infidelity</vocabulary>. Usually only unethical people would cheat on their spouse, right?

Unlike 浮気, which can mean cheating in either dating or marriage, 不倫 is strictly adultery in marriage. It sounds way more serious (and has way bigger consequences). Basically, all 不倫 is 浮気, but not all 浮気 is 不倫… Both are bad, but one may come with legal fees.
<kanji>Ethics</kanji> and <kanji>reason</kanji> together in a person make them have very strong <vocabulary>ethics</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>morals</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>biased</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to be biased</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be prejudiced</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>biased</kanji> way of <kanji>see</kanji>ing is also known as <vocabulary>prejudice</vocabulary>, or just <vocabulary>bias</vocabulary>.

偏見 is often used to describe unfair judgments or opinions based on stereotypes rather than facts.

<kanji>Narrow</kanji> <kanji>biased</kanji> people are considered to be <vocabulary>narrow minded</vocabulary> and they're usually disliked for their <vocabulary>intolerance</vocabulary> of other cultures and anything unfamiliar to them.

People who are <kanji>biased</kanji> about what they <kanji>eat</kanji> usually only eat sweet stuff like candy and ice cream. This <vocabulary>picky eating</vocabulary> gives them a really <vocabulary>unbalanced diet</vocabulary>. Candy and ice cream are okay, but you have to be open to eating other things too.

Someone prone to <kanji>indicate</kanji> and <kanji>instigate</kanji> will have lots of <vocabulary>suggestions</vocabulary> for other people. By dropping <vocabulary>hint</vocabulary>s, they can indicate problems and instigate fights among people. Their <vocabulary>implication</vocabulary>s do a lot of harm.
When a volcano <kanji>erupt</kanji>s with <kanji>fire</kanji> it makes a really big <vocabulary>eruption</vocabulary>. You should probably start running.
Sometimes volcanoes <kanji>erupt</kanji> with just <kanji>smoke</kanji> instead of lava or fire. That's called <vocabulary>volcanic smoke</vocabulary>.
When something <kanji>erupt</kanji>s and <kanji>shoots</kanji> a bunch of water or lava out it comes out in a huge <vocabulary>jet</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>spray</vocabulary>s everything.

<kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>erupts</kanji> from <vocabulary>water fountains</vocabulary>. Sometimes they're big eruptions and sometimes they're small, but they're always fun to watch and enjoy in the hot summer.

When something <kanji>erupt</kanji>s out an <kanji>exit</kanji> it usually had to fight pretty hard to get to that exit. That's why it ends up <vocabulary>spewing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>gushing</vocabulary> all over the place.
An <kanji>orphan</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is sadly still an <vocabulary>orphan</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>orphan</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji> is one that's all alone, without any other island friends or family. That's what makes it a <vocabulary>solitary island</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>orphan</kanji> who's <kanji>alone</kanji> is trapped in a world of <vocabulary>isolation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>loneliness</vocabulary>. Having no parents is hard enough, but not having anyone else is even lonelier.

When <kanji>orphan</kanji>s <kanji>stand</kanji>, they stand in <vocabulary>isolation</vocabulary> — <vocabulary>alone</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>friendless</vocabulary>. Orphans don't have any parents, so this world can be a pretty cruel place for them. It's really sad.
A <kanji>lazy</kanji> <kanji>lazy</kanji> person is plagued with never ending <vocabulary>laziness</vocabulary>. They never get up. They just move slowly around the floor.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>neglect</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to be negligent</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to neglect</vocabulary> something.
A <kanji>constant</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is the kind that stays in one place. It's just a regular <vocabulary>star</vocabulary>, like the north star or our sun, not a comet or an asteroid.

<kanji>Constant</kanji> <kanji>example</kanji>s that you use all the time end up becoming part of an <vocabulary>established practice</vocabulary>. You constantly use them so it just stays that way after a while.

A thing that's <kanji>constant</kanji> for a <kanji>long time</kanji> becomes <vocabulary>permanent</vocabulary>. Leave a shoe on the sidewalk for a long time? Permanently stuck there. Constantly making dumb faces? Permanently stuck like that.

Keeping things <kanji>constant</kanji> and <kanji>normal</kanji> ensures <vocabulary>constancy</vocabulary>.

恒常 is a formal word used to describe something that remains <vocabulary>constant</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>unchanging</vocabulary>.

If you have the <kanji>nature</kanji> of being <kanji>lazy</kanji> it will become a <vocabulary>habit</vocabulary>. The <vocabulary>momentum</vocabulary> created by your natural laziness will make it so you can't break out of your lazy cycle.

<kanji>I</kanji> get <kanji>ridiculed</kanji> a lot, but it makes me have really strong <vocabulary>endurance</vocabulary>. If you get picked on a lot, just say, "I have <vocabulary>patience</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>self control</vocabulary>, and I can make it through this."

You <kanji>ridicule</kanji> everyone but your<kanji>self</kanji> because you have so much <vocabulary>pride</vocabulary>. When you talk about yourself you only <vocabulary>boast</vocabulary> because there's nothing to ridicule. That's how great you think you are.

When your <kanji>laziness</kanji> is <kanji>loose</kanji> you can't pull yourself together and you end up moving really <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary>. Your arms and legs get loose and your movements become <vocabulary>sluggish</vocabulary>.

You ignore everything around you because you are <kanji>lazy</kanji> with <kanji>laziness</kanji>. That's too much lazy for one person so you're prone to <vocabulary>negligence</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>procrastination</vocabulary>. You definitely can't manage to take care of things when you're this lazy.

If it's in your <kanji>nature</kanji> to <kanji>ridicule</kanji> people, it will become a <vocabulary>chronic</vocabulary> problem. You can't change something that's so embedded in who you are, which is a shame, since you're a jerk.

<kanji>Embrace</kanji> your duty to <kanji>defend</kanji> your country and prepare for its <vocabulary>protection</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>defense</vocabulary>. You love your country, so you'll do what you have to in order to <vocabulary>support</vocabulary> its defense.
An <kanji>embrace</kanji> and a <kanji>hug</kanji> are pretty much the same thing. So you're still going to <vocabulary>embrace</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>hug</vocabulary> people!

You <kanji>embrace</kanji> someone to keep them <kanji>stand</kanji>ing. You're <vocabulary>backing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>supporting</vocabulary> this person, so no matter what happens you've gotta keep them on their feet.

擁立 is a formal word for backing someone up for a position, usually in politics or organizations. It's used when people unite to promote or nominate someone as a leader or as a political candidate.
To do an <kanji>embrace</kanji> is <vocabulary>to have</vocabulary> that person or animal in your arms. You hug it and then run away with it. It's yours now.
An <kanji>especially</kanji> <kanji>special</kanji> thing is even more <vocabulary>special</vocabulary> and probably a lot more <vocabulary>unique</vocabulary> than ordinary special things.

You're <kanji>especially</kanji> <kanji>win</kanji>ning when you selflessly devote yourself or overcome personal weaknesses. That's what makes it <vocabulary>admirable</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>praiseworthy</vocabulary>!

殊勝 is a formal term often used to describe someone's commendable endurance, sincere attitude, good intentions, or virtuous actions.
When a plant or an animal <kanji>die</kanji>s you have to <vocabulary>discard</vocabulary> it. You can't just keep it sitting around the house after <vocabulary>death</vocabulary>, that's weird.

All the art, music, or books that come out <kanji>after</kanji> a person <kanji>die</kanji>s are considered to be released <vocabulary>after death</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>posthumously</vocabulary>.

When a person <kanji>die</kanji>s in a <kanji>war</kanji> they're considered to have been <vocabulary>killed in action</vocabulary>. There are lots of memorials around the world for people who died this way.

If you <kanji>sink</kanji> and <kanji>die</kanji> it's because you were <vocabulary>sinking</vocabulary> in the ocean or a pool or something. It's important to notice you're <vocabulary>going down</vocabulary> so you don't die like that.
At night the <kanji>sun</kanji> <kanji>die</kanji>s at <vocabulary>sunset</vocabulary>. Don't worry, it will be reborn tomorrow morning at sunrise and everything will be okay.

All the extra things <kanji>die</kanji> in the <kanji>head</kanji> when one is <vocabulary>immersing oneself</vocabulary> in one thing. That way, the thing they're focusing on is the only thing in their brain.

没頭 is a relatively formal word that means being deeply absorbed or engrossed in something. It's often positive and describes a state where someone is so focused on an activity they lose track of time or forget about everything else.

A building or civilization that <kanji>die</kanji>s and then <kanji>falls</kanji> is in a state of <vocabulary>ruin</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>collapse</vocabulary>. Like the Mayans or the Western Roman Empire. They fell pretty hard.

You <kanji>bury</kanji> things into people who look like they've <kanji>die</kanji>d. It's called <vocabulary>implantation</vocabulary>. They're not really dead though. This is surgery and they'll wake up and go about their lives with whatever that thing was that you put in them.

Animals <kanji>exit</kanji> the mountains into your land and never seem to <kanji>die</kanji>! They end up <vocabulary>appearing frequently</vocabulary> in your garden, eating all your yummy carrots and watermelons, and then make their exit back into the hills. They're <vocabulary>infesting</vocabulary> your home now and you don't know what to do!

When you <kanji>obtain</kanji> something acting like that person had <kanji>die</kanji>d, it's called <vocabulary>confiscation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>forfeiture</vocabulary>. Maybe if they were alive, you think, they wouldn't have let me take it. Well they are still alive so it's theirs and you can't keep it forever.
Who do you <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> as an <kanji>offering</kanji> to the gods? A poor <vocabulary>victim</vocabulary> will be your <vocabulary>sacrifice</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
If you can <kanji>teach</kanji> <kanji>hunting</kanji> then you must be a really accomplished <vocabulary>hunter</vocabulary> yourself.
<kanji>Hunting</kanji> in <kanji>secrecy</kanji> is only done through illegal <vocabulary>poaching</vocabulary>. If you weren't poaching protected animals you wouldn't have to do it secretly.
<kanji>Hunting</kanji> where you <kanji>hunt</kanji> is still <vocabulary>hunting</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>hunting</kanji> <kanji>dog</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hunting dog</vocabulary>!

Your <kanji>auspicious</kanji> <kanji>departure</kanji> from another world is your <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary> story. You originally came from another place, and you had to leave there gloriously before you could enter this world.

A <kanji>not</kanji>-<kanji>auspicious</kanji> <kanji>occurrence</kanji> is a <vocabulary>scandal</vocabulary>. A scandal is pretty much the opposite of an auspicious occurrence.

不祥事 refers to a scandal that brings about dishonor, particularly to institutions, organizations, or public figures. It often involves misconduct, corruption, or other unethical behavior that has a significant negative impact on their public image.
The <kanji>preface</kanji> of <kanji>order</kanji> is still <vocabulary>order</vocabulary>. Because order is always prefaced by more order. Order keeps us all in check.

<kanji>Provisions</kanji> you can <kanji>eat</kanji> are still <vocabulary>provisions</vocabulary> and sometimes called <vocabulary>rations</vocabulary>, especially when troops are eating them.

This word often refers to <vocabulary>staple foods</vocabulary> like rice and wheat.
A thing that <kanji>swell</kanji>s <kanji>big</kanji> ends up being <vocabulary>huge</vocabulary> or at least really <vocabulary>bulky</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>swell</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to swell</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to expand</vocabulary>.
You need to <kanji>swell</kanji> and <kanji>stretch</kanji> if you want to see any kind of <vocabulary>expansion</vocabulary> of your company. Growth can't happen without a little wiggle room.

An <kanji>aromatic</kanji> <kanji>fragrance</kanji> is usually a <vocabulary>fragrance</vocabulary> with a <vocabulary>sweet smell</vocabulary>.

芳香 is a formal word for a pleasant, natural fragrance, like the scent of roses. You'll most likely see this in the word 芳香剤 (air fresheners), but it's also used in literature for pleasant aromas.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The kanji is <kanji>aromatic</kanji>, so this also means <vocabulary>aromatic</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fragrant</vocabulary>. 

芳しい is a formal word, often used in writing to describe <vocabulary>sweet-smelling</vocabulary> flowers, tea, or incense. In a figurative sense it can mean "favorable," too, but this meaning mostly appears in the negative form 芳しくない (unfavorable, poorly received).
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

If you have the <kanji>leadership</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji> it means you have a lot of <vocabulary>ambition</vocabulary> to go after the things you want. And you'll be able to lead others because of it.
Those with <kanji>leadership</kanji> who want <kanji>control</kanji> will set out on missions of <vocabulary>conquest</vocabulary> and strive for world <vocabulary>domination</vocabulary>!
Those with the <kanji>rights</kanji> to <kanji>leadership</kanji> have complete <vocabulary>hegemony</vocabulary> over the country. And they will reign until the end of time.
<kanji>Someone</kanji> with the most <kanji>leadership</kanji> is known as the <vocabulary>supreme ruler</vocabulary>. No one has more leadership than them.

If you <kanji>take along</kanji> your <kanji>leadership</kanji> over and over, you're on a <vocabulary>winning streak</vocabulary>! You can expect <vocabulary>successive victories </vocabulary> in <vocabulary>consecutive championships</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>sushi counter</kanji> is counting <vocabulary>one piece of sushi</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>consistency</vocabulary>, which makes sense if you think about piece of sushi—each one should be as consistent as the last! Linked to this, it can also mean <vocabulary>integration</vocabulary>, because integration is easier if there's consistency, after all.

When you <kanji>pierce</kanji> some fabric with a needle it needs to <kanji>pass through</kanji> to the other side to actually <vocabulary>pierce</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>penetrate</vocabulary> it. Make sure it goes all the way through if you want to sew properly.

You have to <kanji>pierce</kanji> this piece of information into your brain until it finally <kanji>penetrate</kanji>s, which takes a lot of <vocabulary>persistence</vocabulary>. Do that and it will be quite the <vocabulary>accomplishment</vocabulary>!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pierce</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to go through</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pierce</vocabulary>.

貫く is a relatively formal word, mostly used in writing. It can mean physically piercing something, but more often it means <vocabulary>to follow through</vocabulary> on your beliefs or goals all the way to the end.

If you <kanji>stab</kanji> to <kanji>pierce</kanji> something, you’d better do it in a <vocabulary>rush</vocabulary>. If you aren't quick enough, you could get into trouble, so rush forth with a mighty charge.

突貫 means doing something in a rush. It’s usually used in the compound 突貫工事, which means fast but often sloppy construction work. It can also describe charging at an enemy, but that meaning is less common today.
<kanji>Compensation</kanji> <kanji>reparation</kanji>s are still <vocabulary>compensation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>reparations</vocabulary>! That's convenient.

You should <kanji>deal with</kanji> and change your <kanji>treatment</kanji> of certain people depending on what kind of situation you're in. This vocab is just the same, making this <vocabulary>dealing with</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>treatment</vocabulary.
The kanji here are <kanji>encounter</kanji> and <kanji>encounter</kanji>, which makes this… <vocabulary>encounter</vocabulary>!

Just because you have to <kanji>wait</kanji> for special <kanji>treatment</kanji> doesn't mean it's not still good <vocabulary>treatment</vocabulary>. And just because everyone didn't cheer when you arrived, doesn't mean you're getting a cold <vocabulary>reception</vocabulary>, you know? Maybe they're planning a surprise party for you or something... yeah.
When you are given <kanji>superior</kanji> <kanji>treatment</kanji> it's called <vocabulary>preferential treatment</vocabulary>. This is the best way to be treated.
When you are given <kanji>cool</kanji> <kanji>treatment</kanji> it's called a <vocabulary>cold reception</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>inhospitality</vocabulary>. This sucks.

The <kanji>treatment</kanji> of your <kanji>boundary</kanji> of your neighborhood is something you should be concerned about, because it's your <vocabulary>environment</vocabulary> and if you don't take care of it, who will?

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>encounter</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to encounter</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to meet</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>encounter</kanji> something <kanji>difficult</kanji> it's going to result in <vocabulary>disaster</vocabulary>. Especially if you're in a boat. Encountering really difficult water will result in a <vocabulary>shipwreck</vocabulary>! Ick!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>country</kanji> in <kanji>chain</kanji>s is under a <vocabulary>national isolation</vocabulary> policy. They're bound and they can't visit anywhere else.

A <kanji>seal</kanji>ed <kanji>chain</kanji> won't break or open so it gets in the way of everyone, forming a <vocabulary>blockade</vocabulary>. This can happen at banks too and it will result in them <vocabulary>freezing</vocabulary> your account!

A <kanji>closed</kanji> <kanji>chain</kanji> lets everyone know that a building or store is <vocabulary>closing</vocabulary> for good. It's got to <vocabulary>lockout</vocabulary> everyone so they won't try to get in anymore.
If you <kanji>take along</kanji> a <kanji>chain</kanji> with you it's still a <vocabulary>chain</vocabulary>, it's just moving somewhere new.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cave in</kanji>, and the verb version takes that feeling further. It means <vocabulary>to fall into</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be thrown into</vocabulary> something negative, like a trap, trouble, or even a bad emotional state.

陥る describes a moment when the world around you or your heart caves in, and you're suddenly thrown into that space and get trapped inside. It's like slipping into a dark hole in life you didn't see coming. That's the feeling!
A <kanji>cave in</kanji> where everyone <kanji>die</kanji>s is still a <vocabulary>cave in</vocabulary>, just a really sad one.

If you <kanji>fall</kanji> during a <kanji>cave in</kanji> you'll <vocabulary>fall</vocabulary> along with everything around you. And that <vocabulary>sinking</vocabulary> feeling in your stomach is because... I mean, well you ARE sinking into the ground.

This item is <kanji>lack</kanji>ing a piece, causing its surface to <kanji>cave in</kanji>. What a <vocabulary>defect</vocabulary>!

欠陥 is a relatively formal word that refers to a <vocabulary>fault</vocabulary> in something, whether in a physical object, a system, or even a plan.

If you keep <kanji>exhibit</kanji>ing the same actions and emotions and phrases eventually they're going to <kanji>rot</kanji> and sound <vocabulary>cliched</vocabulary> to everyone. You have to mix things up once in a while. You don't want to get <vocabulary>stale</vocabulary>, do you?!

An <kanji>exhibit</kanji> of things in a <kanji>row</kanji> only happens at an <vocabulary>exhibition</vocabulary>. Everything will be neatly lined up on <vocabulary>display</vocabulary> for you there.
<kanji>Exhibit</kanji> what you want to <kanji>mention</kanji> in a loud, clear <vocabulary>statement</vocabulary>. You have to say it if you want people to listen.

<kanji>Exhibit</kanji> your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s in a <vocabulary>petition</vocabulary>. If you feel something is unjust you have to say something. Form an <vocabulary>appeal</vocabulary> and fight back!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Something that's <kanji>certain</kanji>ly <kanji>necessary</kanji> is something you can't live without. It's <vocabulary>indispensable</vocabulary>. And it's <vocabulary>required</vocabulary> by you to keep on living.
This is the adverb version of the kanji <kanji>quick</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>quickly</vocabulary>.

Let the <kanji>wind</kanji> in from the window above your <kanji>bath</kanji> so the water is cool enough for you to take a <vocabulary>bath</vocabulary>! If the water is too hot, you'll get all dizzy and that's dangerous!
One <kanji>design</kanji> that you can <kanji>take</kanji> anywhere with you is <vocabulary>cat's cradle</vocabulary>, the game where you loop string around your hands and fingers to create patterns.

This is a <kanji>design</kanji> <kanji>from</kanji> <vocabulary>Ayano</vocabulary>. Do you know an Ayano who's good at designing things? A couple creative Ayanos include traditional Okinawan folk singer and sanshin player Uema Ayano (上間 綾乃), and author Takeda Ayano (武田 綾乃) who won the Yoshikawa Eiji Literary Newcomer Award in 2021.

Who's a <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>help</kanji>? That'll be <vocabulary>Daisuke</vocabulary>!

Famous Daisukes include film director and screenwriter Itō Daisuke (伊藤 大輔), figure skater Takahashi Daisuke (髙橋 大輔), and actor and singer Namikawa Daisuke (浪川 大輔).
When you <kanji>revive</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji>, what you're doing is <vocabulary>resuscitation</vocabulary>. Or, to be less medical, <vocabulary>revival</vocabulary>.

What could a <kanji>purple</kanji> <kanji>revive</kanji> be? This actually means <vocabulary>shiso</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>Japanese perilla</vocabulary>, and it's a type of herb commonly used in Japanese cuisine. You can remember this refers to a plant by the flowers radical in 蘇. You might also want to google "shiso," as you'll notice how some of them have purple leaves!

Note that, as with other plant and tree species, you'll often encounter this being written in katakana as well.
